results.title: Force of the wind
results.creator_credit: Justin Somerville, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Justin Somerville never thought he would be in the middle of a tornado, so his first reaction was that he wanted to witness this phenomena. His account of the aftermath provides detail well beyond the media coverage of the devestation of this small town.
On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado.

results.title: A Trail of destruction
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Somerville, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The whole thing probably lasted about twenty seconds, but for Jeremy Somerville, his family and community, it is an event they will never forget.
On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado.

results.title: Under the stairs
results.creator_credit: Emily Somerville, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
When Emily Somerville first heard the loud bangs in the morning, she thought it was her family making the noise. When she realised it was more serious than that, Somerville and her family took shelter under the stairs, surviving the tornado but finding it hard to control her emotions afterwards.
On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Emily Somerville, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Alfred Milgrom]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Alfred Milgrom, with business partner and marketing expert Naomi Besen, launched Beam Software in 1980. From the company’s beginnings as UK publishing firm, Melbourne House, Milgrom and Besen moved to Australia and opened up their software programming arm with Beam. He reflects on his years in the software industry and the innovations Beam initiated, both in games design and corporate culture.

results.title: [Beam Software: interview 3]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Andrew Bailey and Trevor Nuridin discuss how they both entered the games industry and their work at Beam’s publishing arm, Melbourne House. They talk candidly about the culture at Beam and the reasons why they left to start Tantalus Media together in 1994.

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Greg Barnett]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

After graudating in computer science from Melbourne University, Greg Bennett joined Beam Software in 1982. Inspired by his dual interests in programming and film, Bennett designed and programmed the groundbreaking one-on-one martial arts game ‘The Way of the exploding fist’. He talks about the game industry over the years and the changes, both financial and creative, in relation to his career.

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Bill McIntosh]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Beam Software programmer, Bill McIntosh, left a boring job in the Royal Air Force to join Beam after his wife bought him a computer, which he equates with “plugging in his brain”. He discusses the games he worked on and the culture at Beam, and the financial conditions in Australia that put such companies at risk.

results.title: Twin [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: James Ruse Agricultural High and Nicholas Lee
results.brief_description:
‘Twin’ is a videogame that highlights the importance of self-respect. It is based upon the Hero’s search for those who took away his ‘colour’. As his colour has been taken away, he has been reduced to his black and white form; his own being is split into two. The Hero realises his colour was in fact not stolen and by being able to overcome the puzzles and challenges brought by each level, the Hero begins to respect himself and is ultimately able to retrieve his ‘colours.’

A 2D problem solving/puzzle showing respect starts with self. This trailer illustrates how the game is played.
Under the category ‘Secondary Games’, James Ruse Agricultural High School’s Nicholas Lee, Year 12, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: The Locket
results.brief_description:
It would be easy to discard a worthless, old locket found on the beach but, out of respect for a serviceman in a black and white photo, an old man embarks on a journey to return the memento to its original owner. He travels a long way from his lonely, daily routine and unearths respect for himself and a fallen solider. ‘The Locket’ is a snapshot of a life we don’t know we’re in until something – or someone – snaps you out of it.
Cast Includes: John Murphy, Iris Whitakker, David Jellie, Victoria Upward, Gomer Jones and Nadine Crichton.
Under the category ‘Secondary Live Action’, this independent entry by Blake Borcich, Year 10, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: The World As We Know It
results.creator_credit: Shannon Castle and Sunbury Downs College
results.brief_description:
A figure, shown by stop-motion animation, much like a zombie, walks through a world in pain. The Earth and people on it are being treated unfairly. Only if the figure wakes up to the fact that we need to respect the world and its inhabitants will the world become a better place.
Under the category ‘Secondary Animation’, Sunbury Downs College’s Shannon Castle, Year 9, was the Screen It 2011 winner.
